docs.lead_paragraph: ANNE WOLFSON, a tall, curly-haired brunette who is told that she smiles a lot, was married in a blue dress from Loehmann's in her late 30's, and began trying to conceive. After a miscarriage, her doctor sent her to a specialist; the specialist could find nothing wrong with her. A year later, a second miscarriage followed, and nine months later, a third. Along the way, she took ovulation pills, injected herself with hormones and embarked on two cycles of in vitro fertilization. She and her husband had spent $45,000, little of it covered by insurance, and the reproductive endocrinologist was starting to talk about using donor eggs.

headline.main: Happiness, Too, Dances on the Head of a Pin

docs.abstract: Anemona Hartocollis Coping column on Dr Rong-Bao Lu, Chinatown acupuncturist who has helped Anne Wolfson conceive baby after three miscarriages; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATS grouse that President Bush has recklessly frittered away the surpluses of the 1990's. Foreign finance ministers plan to express their alarm about America's Brobdingnagian budget deficit at a Group of 7 meeting in Boca Raton, Fla., this weekend. Even a growing number of Republicans argue that Mr. Bush needs to stop making excuses and cut government spending. So what is the reaction from the bond market vigilantes, those disciplinarians who bid up interest rates whenever past deficits started looming? Yawn.

headline.main: That Big Fat Budget Deficit. Yawn.

docs.abstract: Concerns about mounting federal budget deficit have failed to spur big jump in bond interest rates; many economists say bond market's muted reaction is both symbol and cause of misplaced calm about deficits; say rapid fiscal swings of last 20 years have creaded false sense of security about deficits, possibly reinforced by accounting moves in Pres Bush's new budget that mask deficit's true size; budget and interest rate graphs; photos (M)
